abstract.text: A view that embeds web content in your app.
A view that embeds web content in your app.
Sets the main page content and base URL.
Connects to a given URL by initiating an asynchronous client request.
Stops the loading of any web content managed by the receiver.
A Boolean value indicating whether the receiver is done loading content.
Loads the previous location in the back-forward list.
Loads the next location in the back-forward list.
A Boolean value indicating whether the receiver can move backward.
A Boolean value indicating whether the receiver can move forward.
The types of data converted to clickable URLs in the web view’s content.
Constants that define the types of information to detect in text-based content.
A Boolean value determining whether the webpage scales to fit the view and the user can change the scale.
The receiver’s delegate.
The
protocol defines methods that a delegate of a
object can optionally implement to intervene when web content is loaded.
Find a suitable alternative to handle your app’s web content.
Sets the main page contents, MIME type, content encoding, and base URL.
The URL request identifying the location of the content to load.
Reloads the current page.
A Boolean value that determines whether pressing on a link displays a preview of the destination for the link.
The scroll view associated with the web view.
A Boolean value indicating whether the web view suppresses content rendering until it is fully loaded into memory.
A Boolean value indicating whether web content can programmatically display the keyboard.
Returns the result of running a JavaScript script. Although this method is not deprecated, best practice is to use the
method of the
class instead.
A Boolean value that determines whether HTML5 videos play inline or use the native full-screen controller.
A Boolean value that determines whether HTML5 videos can play automatically or require the user to start playing them.
A Boolean value that determines whether Air Play is allowed from this view.
A Boolean value that determines whether Picture in Picture playback is allowed from this view.
The size of the gap, in points, between pages.
The number of pages produced by the layout of the web view.
The size of each page, in points, in the direction that the pages flow.
The manner in which column- or page-breaking occurs.
The layout of content in the web view.
A Boolean value indicating whether telephone number detection is on.
Constant indicating the user’s action.
The manner in which column- or page-breaking occurs.
The layout of content in the web view, which determines the direction that the pages flow.
A view that shows that a task is in progress.
An object that displays a single image or a sequence of animated images in your interface.
A view that uses a spinning-wheel or slot-machine metaphor to show one or more sets of values.
A view that depicts the progress of a task over time.

inlineContent.text: In apps that run in iOS 8 and later, use the
class instead of using
. Additionally, consider setting the
property
to
if you render files that are not supposed to run JavaScript.
An iOS app linked on or after iOS 10.0 must include in its
file the usage description keys for the types of data it needs to access or it will crash. To access a user’s photo data specifically, it must include
and
Use the
method to begin loading local HTML files or the
method to begin loading web content. Use the
method to stop loading, and the
property to find out if a web view is in the process of loading.
If you allow the user to move back and forward through the webpage history, then you can use the
and
methods as actions for buttons. Use the
and
properties to disable the buttons when the user can’t move in a direction.

By default, a web view automatically converts telephone numbers that appear in web content to Phone links. When a Phone link is tapped, the Phone app launches and dials the number. To turn off this default behavior, set the
property with a
bitfield that does not contain the
flag.
You can also use the
property to programmatically set the scale of web content the first time it is displayed in a web view. Thereafter, the user can change the scale using gestures.
Set the
property to an object conforming to the
protocol if you want to track the loading of web content.
You should not embed
or
objects in
objects. If you do so, unexpected behavior can result because touch events for the two objects can be mixed up and wrongly handled.
You can easily debug the HTML, CSS, and JavaScript contained inside a
with Web Inspector. Read Debugging Web Content on iOS to learn how to configure Web Inspector for iOS. Read the rest of
to learn how to create web content that is optimized for Safari on iPhone and iPad.
For information about basic view behaviors, see
In addition to HTML content,
objects can be used to display other content types, such as Keynote, PDF, and Pages documents. For the best rendering of plain and rich text in your app, however, you should use
instead.
In iOS 6 and later, if you assign a value to this view’s

property, it attempts to preserve its URL history,  the scaling and scrolling positions for each page, and information about which page is currently being viewed. During restoration, the view restores these values so that the web content appears just as it did before. For more information about how state preservation and restoration works, see
For more information about appearance and behavior configuration, see
The
class should not be subclassed.
